posts.title: Prompt teardown: messy meeting notes -> exec summary (with evidence links)
posts.content: Took a 14-minute Zoom transcript with speakers overtalking and produced a 180-word exec summary + 5 evidence links. Used role = "operational analyst", explicit section headers, and a bullet-for-bullet trace of how each link is picked. Added a guardrail: refuse to invent links. Sharing the exact template + two bad examples that I debugged.

posts.title: Shipped a tiny RAG for onboarding docs in 2 hours — stack + eval notes
posts.content: Used the practice zone retrieval pattern to wire up a RAG over onboarding docs: Qdrant + 768-dim embeddings, 600-token chunks, overlap 120, rerank with Cohere, then a tight synthesis prompt. Baseline hallucinated PTO policy; after adding a "show gaps" step and scoring with 20 synthetic eval Qs, hallucination rate dropped from 18% to 2%.

posts.title: Duel recap: beat the zero-shot baseline 7-5 using prompt unit tests
posts.content: Queued a duel vs. the default template for summarizing customer tickets. I wrote 6 micro-tests (one-hot edge cases, sarcasm, mixed languages) and iterated until each passed. Net gain: +9 prompt score, +41 upvotes. Dropping the test harness and the exact "failing example" section I include in the prompt so the model self-checks before responding.

posts.title: Question: chunking voice transcripts for agentic flows?
posts.content: Working on call coaching. Transcripts are 20-30 minutes and I need an agent to detect objections + suggest responses without missing context. Anyone have a rule-of-thumb for chunk size/overlap and whether to pre-label speaker turns? I'm testing 480-token chunks with 120 overlap and storing speaker as metadata but open to better patterns.

posts.title: Resource: prompt QA checklist I use before shipping
posts.content: Quick checklist I run for every prompt change: 1) Define success/fail examples, 2) Add a "what not to do" block, 3) Set output schema + refusal policy, 4) Add two contrastive few-shots, 5) Run eval set with 10 red-team prompts, 6) Track deltas in a simple CSV. Includes the template I paste inside the prompt to nudge self-checks.

posts.title: Project share: auto-coach that tags rubric gaps after each practice step
posts.content: Built a small auto-coach for my practice sessions. It stores each step, scores with our rubric (clarity/constraints/iteration/tool), and suggests one tweak before I move on. Uses a "keep/kill/change" pattern so feedback stays concise. Seeing +11 prompt score over three days. Code + prompt attached.

posts.title: Practice Zone speedrun: Level 1 fundamentals in 11 minutes (score 86)
posts.content: Tried a speedrun: Level 1 fundamentals, all 12 prompts in 11 minutes. Highest lift came from rewriting the instruction order and adding a pre-flight "restate the constraints" step. Sharing a Loom + my notes on which prompts were traps.

posts.title: Prompt pattern: diagnostic tree for broken outputs
posts.content: When outputs drift, I run a diagnostic tree: 1) ask model to classify failure type (missing constraints vs hallucination vs tone), 2) request a "minimal patch" suggestion, 3) re-run with patch and compare deltas. It cuts debug time in half. Dropping the exact system prompt + a before/after example from a pricing email.

posts.title: Using retrieval + function calls to enforce boundaries with clients
posts.content: Freelance prompt ops: I built a guardrail that checks whether the answer stays inside the retrieved context *before* it goes out. Using a two-call pattern: retrieval -> "policy validator" prompt -> final generation. Anyone else doing this? Curious if you auto-flag and store violations.

posts.title: Ask: best way to report prompt score deltas to leadership?
posts.content: I need a quick way to show "we improved prompts" without overwhelming non-technical execs. Thinking a single slide: prompt score delta, community score delta, and 2 examples of before/after outputs. Anyone have a template or metric set that resonates?

posts.title: Mini dataset: 25 red-team prompts for hallucination hunts
posts.content: Built a tiny eval set to smoke out hallucinations on policy answers: tricky date math, inverted names, and "impossible" questions that should refuse. Running it nightly against my RAG stack and tracking refusal rate + citation coverage. CSV + prompt harness attached.

posts.title: Maker log: weekend experiment with multi-agent critique
posts.content: Tried a lightweight 2-agent loop: drafter -> critic -> drafter. For marketing copy it improved tone, but for data tasks it hallucinated more. Key lesson: constrain the critic to ONLY label violations of the rubric, not rewrite. Curious if anyone got multi-agent to outperform a single well-structured prompt here.

posts.title: Win: first paying client from my prompt portfolio
posts.content: Posted my prompt portfolio last week (screenshots + scores). Landed a $1.2k/mo retainer to maintain their support macros. Biggest hook was showing prompt score improvements alongside before/after outputs. If you haven't filled your portfolio, do it — it's working.

posts.title: Feedback wanted: onboarding email rewrite prompt
posts.content: Trying to tighten an onboarding email prompt for a fintech client. Goal: 120 words, 1 CTA, no jargon. Current issue: model adds legal caveats. Prompt includes an "off-limits" section but it's still leaking. If you spot holes, please roast it — snippet in comments.

comments.content: Ran this on our CS standup. Adding "list unresolved decisions" made the exec summary instantly usable. Thanks for the few-shot contrasts.
+1 on the evidence links. I also append "if no evidence, say so explicitly" to stop it from guessing.
If you want less fluff, add a "verbs only" pass: ask it to rewrite bullets starting with a verb + owner.
Love the gap step. Did you try sentence-window retrieval instead of 600-token chunks? Curious if it reduced repeats.
What eval model are you using for the nightly run? I'm stuck between GPT-4o mini and Claude Haiku for cost reasons.
That "failing example" block is gold. I copy-pasted and my refusal rate on sensitive tickets improved.
If you can, also log which micro-test failed during duels. Makes it easier to prioritize fixes.
Try labeling objection spans during retrieval. Then have the agent plan a "respond vs park" decision before generating.
I had better recall with 360-token chunks + 25% overlap. Also store speaker role; it reduces weird attributions.
Saved. I added a "describe two failure modes" line so the model self-critiques before final output.
Thank you for the CSV idea — way lighter than spinning up a dashboard.
How are you storing rubric history? Thinking of logging per-step deltas so I can see where I regress.
Seconding this. I keep a column for "constraint violations" and it makes patterns obvious after a week.
Speedrun king/queen! Did you preload any few-shots or pure instructions?
Tried this on a tone issue. The "minimal patch" step is underrated — stopped the model from rewriting everything.
Do you ever ask it to propose tests after the patch? Thinking of chaining it with Leo's unit tests idea.
I auto-flag violations to a Slack channel with the offending span highlighted. Keeps clients happy.
Single slide: prompt score delta, top 2 risks removed, and one "before/after" card. Works great for execs.
Nice set. Add a "should refuse" label per row so you can separate refusals from bad citations in metrics.
If you release v2, I'd love 5 finance-specific red-teamers. Happy to co-create.
I saw the same. Critic started hallucinating constraints. Switched to a checklist critic and it stabilized.
For marketing copy I cap the critic to 3 bullets: tone, evidence, compliance. Anything more and it derails.
Huge congrats! Did you include Looms or just screenshots in the portfolio?
Here’s the prompt snippet: system = "Fintech onboarding coach", hard limits on legal text, and a {company_tone} variable. Model still adds "consult your advisor" — ideas?
Add a refusal policy: if legal/financial advice is requested, ask a clarifying question instead. Also add a "tone: confident, not legal" line.
